text: When Thursday afternoon began, the Wimbledon women’s singles final held the possibility of featuring a new mother from Ukraine taking on a player seeking to become the first woman from an Arab country to win a Grand Slam singles title, or her facing a Belarusian in a match that would overflow with wartime tension.

headline: Carlo Vittorini, Publisher Who Lifted Parade Magazine, Dies at 94
text: Carlo Vittorini, who as publisher guided Parade magazine, the nearly ubiquitous weekly Sunday newspaper supplement, to revenue and circulation heights, died on June 25 at his summer home in Nantucket, Mass. He was 94.

headline: U.S. to Pay $975,000 to Resolve Sexual Assault Claims Against Air Force General
text: The federal government has agreed to pay a retired Army colonel $975,000 to resolve a lawsuit she filed in 2019 that accused John E. Hyten, an Air Force general who later became vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, of sexual assault, according to court records.

headline: Hollywood Actors Vote to Strike
text: About 160,000 television and movie actors will join screenwriters who walked off the job in May, setting off the first industrywide shutdown in 63 years.

headline: Once ‘The Nanny,’ Now Center Stage as the Actors’ Union Leader
text: The stage was different, and so was the tone. But the voice was unmistakable.

headline: Elina Svitolina’s Love Affair With Wimbledon Ends, but U.S. Open Awaits
text: One fan in Centre Court held the Ukrainian flag. Another yelled, “We love you, Elina.” The Ukrainian ambassador was there, too, cheering along with fans from Britain, the United States, Uganda, Bulgaria and more, for Elina Svitolina, the uncrowned sentimental champion of Wimbledon 2023.

headline: Aspartame Is a Possible Cause of Cancer in Humans, a W.H.O. Agency Says
text: A World Health Organization agency declared on Thursday that aspartame, an artificial sweetener widely used in diet drinks and low-sugar foods, could possibly cause cancer.

headline: Breaking Up With Diet Soda? Here Are 11 Aspartame-Free Alternatives.
text: The World Health Organization declared Thursday that the artificial sweetener aspartame is “possibly carcinogenic to humans,” adding it to the same risk category as breathing in engine exhaust, working in dry-cleaning and consuming certain pickled vegetables.

headline: Prosecutors Push Back on Trump’s Request to Delay Documents Trial
text: Federal prosecutors on Thursday asked the judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case to reject a motion by Mr. Trump’s lawyers to have his trial indefinitely postponed, a move that could serve to delay the proceeding until after the 2024 election.

headline: Russian General Denounces His Bosses as Officers Are Fired or Questioned
text: A top Russian general in Ukraine has lashed out at his bosses after being fired from his command, accusing them of undermining the war effort with dishonesty and politicking, in the latest sign of turmoil within the Kremlin’s military leadership.

headline: ‘As Long as It Takes’: Biden Adds to Talk of a New Cold War
text: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.

headline: The W.H.O. Says Aspartame Is ‘Possibly Carcinogenic.’ What Does That Mean?
text: On Thursday, two World Health Organization agencies released their findings on aspartame, the artificial sweetener found in thousands of sugar-free products like diet sodas, chewing gums, yogurts and energy drinks.

headline: Butcher Who Assaulted Officers on Jan. 6 Is Sentenced to 7 Years in Prison
text: A butcher from Maine who assaulted five police officers during the riot at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Thursday to more than seven years in prison.

headline: ‘Human Beings Are Soon Going to Be Eclipsed’
text: Recently I stumbled across an essay by Douglas Hofstadter that made me happy. Hofstadter is an eminent cognitive scientist and the author of books like “Gödel, Escher, Bach” and “I Am a Strange Loop.” The essay that pleased me so much, called “The Shallowness of Google Translate,” was published in The Atlantic in January of 2018.

headline: Bipartisan Measure Aims to Force Release of U.F.O. Records
text: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader, is pushing legislation to create a commission with broad authority to declassify government documents about U.F.O.s and extraterrestrial matters, in an attempt to force the government to share all that it knows about unidentified phenomena.

headline: Lisa Marie Presley Died From Bowel Obstruction, Officials Say
text: Lisa Marie Presley, the singer-songwriter and only child of Elvis Presley, died in January as a result of “a small bowel obstruction” caused by scar tissue that developed after bariatric surgery years ago, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner’s office said on Thursday.

headline: Syria Authorizes U.N. Use of Border Crossing for Aid, Giving Itself Oversight
text: Syria announced on Thursday that it would give state approval for the United Nations to deliver humanitarian aid into rebel-held northern areas through a contentious border crossing with Turkey, effectively giving President Bashar al-Assad’s government control over all aid deliveries to the northern areas of the country.

headline: They’re Full of Pop
text: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — Today brings the second Times acrostic from David Balton and Jane Stewart. It draws from the 1995 memoir by Barack Obama called “Dreams From My Father.” Nineteen ninety-five? I had to look it up: It was indeed written and published when Mr. Obama was a law professor at the University of Chicago. The book has sold over seven million copies, and even those of us who didn’t read it probably know some biographical information about the 44th president.

headline: Fire Kills Dozens of Animals at a Florida Rescue Center
text: It was a refuge for abandoned exotic pets that Floridians could no longer care for, as well as for orphaned native wildlife, including chinchillas, skunks, stingrays, lizards and alligators — around 250 of them, all told.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Women in Congress Put Equal Rights Amendment Back on the Agenda
text: “We can’t let paperwork keep us out of the U.S. Constitution.”

headline: A New Life and a New Name, Both Inspired by Nature
text: When Shira Claudelle Catlin and Morgan Joan Keith met, they didn’t waste much time becoming an official couple. Almost one month to the day after connecting on Tinder, they became exclusive.

headline: He Was Spinning Vinyl. She Spun His World Around.
text: One day in March 2021, Chloe Dulce Louvouezo was on her way to a coffee shop to tackle a creative exercise in “The Artist’s Way” workbook before meeting a friend for lunch.

headline: After Abandoning a Dating App, He Found His Match on Twitter
text: In April 2020, during the early days of the pandemic, Peter Elliot Rosenberg, a broadcaster for Hot 97, ESPN New York and the World Wrestling Entertainment, had been hosting his radio show from his apartment on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. During that time, Mr. Rosenberg, recently divorced, began to entertain the idea of dating.

headline: What Happens When You Ask a Chinese Chatbot About Taiwan?
text: Last month, China’s Baidu unveiled a chatbot that it claimed was better than ChatGPT, the one developed by Silicon Valley’s OpenAI. ChatGPT was released last fall and set off a fund-raising and engineering frenzy in a flourishing field called generative artificial intelligence, a term for technology that can create text or images when prompted by a user.

headline: India Launches Lunar Mission With a Shot at Winning This Year’s Moon Race
text: India is on its way back to the moon after a rocket lifted off from Sriharikota, a launch site off the country’s East Coast, on Friday afternoon local time.

headline: A Breakup That Was the Best Thing to Happen to Them
text: When Isaac Leon Archuleta and Joseph Daniel Jones reconnected after four years apart, they learned that a breakup can actually be a gift. From 2010 to 2014, they were in an on-and-off relationship, wrestling with issues that could only be reconciled with time and space. Then, they broke up for good.

headline: With Offices Vacant, London’s Canary Wharf Seeks Growth Beyond Banking
text: The gleaming skyscrapers of London’s east skyline, built almost 40 years ago, are home to the headquarters of the world’s biggest banks and tens of thousands of their office workers.

headline: The Strawberry Fields of Wimbledon
text: It was midmorning and the sun was still rising across the English countryside, but Shakhboz Yakhshiboev had been awake since the early hours. Against the backdrop of first light, Yakhshiboev had been making his way through one of the many 50-yard-long polytunnels that were his assignment for these two weeks.

headline: My Fetish for a Second Skin
text: Growing up Korean American in a pearly white city at the foot of the Rocky Mountains, I often wanted out of my own skin.

headline: A Century Ago, Golf Fans Watched a ‘Do-or-Die’ Moment
text: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a moment in the history of golf that will be recreated where it happened 100 years ago tomorrow. We’ll also get details on why there will probably be more squabbling over the maps for New York’s congressional districts.

headline: Name That Tune (and the Bird Behind It)
text: This week, we invite participants to try birding by ear. Practice identifying five species common to your area by their vocalizations. The Sound ID feature of the free Merlin Bird ID app can offer suggestions for which species are calling or singing around you. (People who are deaf or hard-of-hearing may find Merlin’s spectrograms helpful as visual representations of the sounds.)

headline: Your Friday Briefing
text: A Hollywood union that represents 160,000 television and movie actors approved a strike yesterday for the first time in 43 years, bringing the $134 billion American movie and television business to a halt over anger about pay and fears of a tech-dominated future.

headline: Europe Keeps Acting Like It Can’t Defend Itself Against Russia
text: Since President Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, the narrative of American and European officialdom has been that Russia, a predatory state, is bent on dominating its neighbors, constituting a grave military threat to all of Europe. Finland’s and Sweden’s decisions to join NATO bolster this proposition, and the alliance appeared to accept it at face value during its summit this week in Vilnius, Lithuania.

headline: House Narrowly Passes Defense Bill, Setting Up Showdown Over Social Issues
text: Republicans on Friday rammed through the House a deeply partisan defense bill that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel, setting up a showdown with the Senate. The coming fight could imperil the crucial annual measure to provide a pay raise for troops, set defense policy to counter U.S. adversaries and sustain Pentagon programs at a time of rising threats.

headline: Word of the Day: adroit
text: The word adroit has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 12 in “The Premier League Crucible Produces Something New: Ideas” by Rory Smith:

headline: Cluster munitions reach Ukraine a week after Biden’s announcement.
text: U.S.-provided cluster munitions have arrived in Ukraine, U.S. and Ukrainian officials have said, a week after President Biden announced he had made the “very difficult decision” to provide Kyiv with the widely banned weapon.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
text: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A.I. Wrote a Housing Bill. Critics Say It’s Not Intelligent.
text: These days it seems like the reach of artificial intelligence knows no bounds, from generating images, prose and jokes to automating various work functions. But the technological advances can carry hidden costs.

headline: Will There Ever Be Another Popular Mayor of New York City?
text: In the early 1990s, the historian Melvin Holli set out to solve a problem with a book called “America’s Big City Mayors.” Although governing a place like New York or Philadelphia was one of the most important political jobs in the country, we had no scholarly ranking of mayors, no orderly system of evaluating them as we did for presidents, thanks to the work of midcentury academics. Relying on surveys of biographers, social scientists and experts in urban policy and on an elaborate methodology, Mr. Holli concluded that Fiorello La Guardia was the best mayor in the history of the United States. No other New York mayor appeared on the “best” list; three were included among the worst.

headline: Insurer’s Retreat in Florida Signals Crisis With No Easy Fix
text: Insurers are trapped in a riddle: In a world where the risk of costly disasters is rising but high premiums are squeezing policyholders and angering state regulators, how can they continue to make money?

headline: Finally, Bill de Blasio Wins New Yorkers’ Praise. For His Breakup.
text: As a two-term Democratic mayor of New York City, Bill de Blasio earned mixed reviews, at best. But now that he’s out of office, he’s getting raves for the way he is handling an unexpected development: his separation from his wife and the transformation of their marriage.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
text: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the latest film in the “Mission Impossible” franchise.

headline: Help! My Boss Won’t Stop Using ChatGPT
text: This week, we answer more of your questions, like: What is ChatGPT’s carbon footprint? Why are engineers so sure artificial intelligence will keep getting better? And, why are there so many venture capital bros?

headline: Hunching Over Your Computer Like a Buzzard Is Not Helping Your Back
text: My fragrance of choice for the past year is eau de menthol pain patch. I’ve had chronic back pain, but the cause is not a mystery: I hunch over my computer for hours at a time. Call it “online spine,” “computer-generated back pain,” or, in my case, “Mac back.”

headline: What Really Happened in the Midterms?
text: More than eight months later, all the data from the 2022 midterm elections is — finally — final. The two most rigorous reports, from the Pew Research Center and Catalist, are finished.

headline: What Tom Hanks Thinks of America
text: The decorated actor discusses his new novel, the magic of typewriters and his read of the American psyche.

headline: Putting the Rich World of Philadelphia’s Public Art Online
text: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.

headline: How to Preserve Priceless Documents at the National Archives
text: The Declaration of Independence. The Bill of Rights. Documents from the present day. And, of course, classified papers once held by presidents of the United States.

headline: The Gatekeepers of Knowledge Don’t Want Us to See What They Know
text: We are living through an information revolution. The traditional gatekeepers of knowledge — librarians, journalists and government officials — have largely been replaced by technological gatekeepers — search engines, artificial intelligence chatbots and social media feeds.

headline: Some Squirmy Stowaways Got to the Arctic. And They Like It There.
text: Worms are on the move, and people are nervous.

headline: Britain’s Conservatives Are Imploding
text: Almost the first thing I saw when I arrived in the London suburb of Uxbridge was two teenage girls in school uniforms getting into a fistfight in the shopping mall outside the underground station. Uxbridge is a middle-class place, stodgy but diversifying, whose voters are squeezed by a cost of living crisis and anxious about rising public disorder. Until last month, it was represented by Boris Johnson, and, as the Labour lawmaker Steve Reed told me, it hasn’t sent a member of the left-leaning Labour Party to Parliament since 1966.

headline: If Loneliness Is an Epidemic, How Do We Treat It?
text: Stephanie Cacioppo thought she would be single forever. “I was an only child,” says Dr. Cacioppo. “I always thought that was my fate to be alone.”

headline: A Federal Judge Asks: Does the Supreme Court Realize How Bad It Smells?
text: What has gone wrong with the Supreme Court’s sense of smell?

headline: A Beach Town Where Broken People Go to Disappear
text: If you, like me, lament the absence in modern-day Hollywood of the whip-smart neo-noir thrillers that flourished in the 1990s — films like “One False Move,” “The Last Seduction,” “After Dark, My Sweet,” “Red Rock West” and “Out of Sight,” to name a few — then I have great news for you. It comes in the form of Dwyer Murphy’s second novel, “The Stolen Coast,” which offers all the abundant pleasures of those films, and more.

headline: At American Apparel, a Sex-Positive Veneer Belied Abuse Underneath
text: After a chance meeting with a recruiter at a dive bar in the winter of 2005, Kate Flannery walked into American Apparel’s Los Angeles headquarters wearing tight surf shorts and her mother’s floppy felt hat. That day — as Flannery writes in her first book, “Strip Tees,” a racy, thoughtful memoir of her tenure during the rise and fall of the controversial company — she watched garment workers produce “quivering piles of kelly-green men’s underwear”; posed for Polaroids in a leg-baring velour romper; and encountered the company’s brash, charismatic founder, Dov Charney, “a flip phone pressed to one ear while another waited in a holster on his belt loop.”

headline: When Did Humans First Occupy the Americas? Ask the Sloth Bones.
text: Of all the long-running disputes in archaeology, few roil scholars more than the question of when humans arrived in the Americas. For much of the past century, the reigning theory was that in or around 11,500 years ago big-game hunters from Asia trudged to North America across a land bridge spanning the Bering Strait, hung a right through a corridor between glaciers and, in less than a millennium, reached the tip of South America.

headline: He Followed in the Family Footsteps. And He Found a Home.
text: Anthony Couverthier’s father was a building superintendent. His brother is a super, too. His longtime partner’s stepfather also works as a super. But Mr. Couverthier spent years trying to be something else: a tour manager for a hip-hop group, a store clerk at Sprint, a Home Depot employee. After graduating high school in 1998, he was a communications major at Stony Brook University in Southampton.

headline: For Many Small-Business Owners, a Necessary Shift to Digital Payments
text: “Making It Work” is a series about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.

headline: Uruguay Saw Opportunity in China. It Got Schooled in the Hazards of Trade.
text: Word that Uruguay was seeking a trade deal with China prompted exultation at El Álamo ranch, a lush expanse of grass punctuated by cactus and herds of cattle on the eastern plains of Uruguay.

headline: 5 Restaurants in Naples Where You Can Forget About Pizza
text: The worldwide culinary fame of Italy’s third-largest city boils down to one word: pizza. You can hardly hurl a tomato in the food’s purported birthplace — a scruffy, graffiti-stained port city of monumental Baroque buildings and narrow cobbled passageways — without hitting a gaggle of culinary pilgrims jockeying to enter one of the hundreds (or thousands, by some counts) of pizzerias.

headline: In Ontario, a Tiny Cabin With Style to Spare
text: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the rotting 19th-century structure resulted in something better.

headline: Saying Goodbye to the Dead. (Again.)
text: The first time Albie Cullen said goodbye to the Grateful Dead was on Aug. 9, 1995.

headline: At 600 Square Feet, the Cabin Was Big Enough: ‘It’s Just Me and My Dog’
text: When Stephan Weishaupt began looking for a weekend home outside Toronto, buying a 19th-century log cabin was the furthest thing from his mind.

headline: Ruined, Empty, Mined and Overgrown: Ukraine’s Forgotten Villages
text: Leave the eastern Ukrainian city of Izium and turn west onto rougher roads, where dead trees and twisted power lines give way to a string of shattered villages.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, July 14, 2023
text: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: The Strangest Trees Grow in East Hampton
text: The clone of the tree that grew from a seed that went to the moon doesn’t look like much. It’s still a callow sapling, a flurry of bright green leaves on a spindly six-foot trunk. But in 20 years or so, this American sycamore will be a formidable presence at the Folly Tree Arboretum, an unusual collection of some 250 trees planted by Tucker Marder, a 33-year-old artist, on five acres of his family’s land in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Today’s Top News: Hollywood Actors Go on Strike, and More
text: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: How Clarence Thomas Came to Reject Affirmative Action
text: Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, the second Black justice to sit on the court after Thurgood Marshall, has spent years opposing affirmative action. When the high court struck down the policy last month, Justice Thomas was one of the most influential figures behind the ruling.

headline: Risk, Regulation and Personal Responsibility in Australia’s Last Frontier
text: Standing in line outside a fireworks store in Darwin on the morning of July 1, a man mentioned to me that he had acquired some kind of metal pipe, out of which he was planning to shoot fireworks that night. It was morning, and the store hadn’t opened yet, but he had wanted to arrive early to beat the rush on the one day a year when residents could buy and set off fireworks.

headline: Corrections: July 14, 2023
text: An obituary on July 3 about the meteorologist Frank Field misstated where he was born. It was Brooklyn, not Queens. It also misstated when his wife, Joan, died. It was last year, not this year. And it omitted the name of a survivor. In addition to those named, Dr. Field is survived by a brother, Allan.

headline: The Semiconductor Struggle
text: Publicly, the U.S. and China have turned down the heat recently on their relationship. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Secretary of State Antony Blinken have both visited Beijing in recent weeks partly to improve communication between the two countries. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the U.S. and China through the frame of great-power conflict,” Yellen said at the end of her trip.

headline: Investors Look for Reasons the Market Could ‘Grind Higher’
text: As companies prepare to open their books to investors over the coming weeks, in the quarterly ritual known as earnings season, market watchers are balancing relatively weak estimates for past profits with brighter forecasts for future performance.

headline: A Ukrainian commander describes the grueling battle against dug-in Russian forces.
text: Even as he commanded troops in a fierce, weeklong fight to capture one Russian position, Col. Viktor Sikoza received disturbing news: The Russians were using this time to build yet another fortification behind it.

headline: The Economic Stakes in the Hollywood Shutdown
text: It’s happening: America’s $134 billion movie and TV industry has ground to a halt after the Hollywood actors’ union voted to strike, joining screenwriters and shutting down virtually all productions.

headline: JPMorgan’s Profit Jumps, but Interest Rates Remain a Threat
text: JPMorgan Chase, the largest lender in the United States, made $14.5 billion in profit last quarter, a big jump from the same period last year, it reported on Friday. The bank was helped by growth virtually across the board, including increases in lending and credit-card transactions, as well as relative stability in investment banking. JPMorgan’s stock rose 0.6 percent at the close of trading.

headline: Extreme Weather Hits Europe, and It’s Not Over Yet
text: Extreme weather has battered Southern Europe and North Africa this month, with sweltering heat aggravating conditions for wildfires in some countries and thunderous storms leading to flooding in others.

headline: Tropical Storm Calvin Passes South of Hawaii
text: Tropical Storm Calvin passed just south of Hawaii on Wednesday, bringing high winds, dangerous surf and heavy rainfall even as it moved away from the Big Island, forecasters said.

headline: Wells Fargo Beats Expectations but Sets Aside Money for Loan Losses
text: Higher interest rates and rising loan balances helped Wells Fargo top analysts’ expectations for the second quarter, even as it socked away more money as a buffer against bad loans.

headline: How a Jay-Z Retrospective Took Over the Brooklyn Public Library
text: Earlier this week, when passages of Jay-Z lyrics from songs like “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)” and “Justify My Thug” appeared on the Art Deco-style, curved limestone facade of the Brooklyn Public Library’s main branch, fans and passers-by could only speculate on the occasion for the building’s sudden makeover. A surprise concert for the rapper’s home borough? A tribute to the 50th anniversary of hip-hop this summer?

headline: A French Music Maker Lost His Voice. A Comedian Helped Get It Back.
text: Guilhem Gallart used to speak with a thick, southern French accent, his voice deep and slightly nasal, topped by a faint lisp.

headline: It’s Been a Good Stretch for the Markets, but Not as Good as It Looks
text: It has been a fine half year for stocks, money market funds and, to a lesser extent, bonds — so good, in comparison with last year, that you may feel like celebrating when you look at your quarterly portfolio statement.

headline: Hollywood Actors Join in California’s ‘Hot Labor Summer’
Water Bills Are Rising. Here’s What to Do About It.
text: Scorching temperatures blanketing much of the country make cool showers enticing. But beware the water bill.

headline: Two Filmmakers, Two Dramas and the Pain of the Foster-Care System
text: “Earth Mama” opens with a fake-out: a young Black woman named Gia (Tia Nomore) happily tickling a cooing newborn. But as the camera pulls away, a more ambivalent reality is exposed. The baby belongs to an older couple visiting the mall portrait studio to take their family photo, while Gia, very much pregnant, wistfully gazes after them.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 6: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
text: Update, July 28: You can submit your response for Week 8 here.

headline: Louis Langrée Wraps Up a Quietly Transformative Era of Conducting
text: Rehearsals led by the conductor Louis Langrée tend to follow a trajectory. Early on, he speaks poetically and tells stories; during preparations for a May concert with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, where he is the music director, he explained Saint-Saëns with references to the Kyrie of a Mass and the paintings of Hieronymus Bosch. But then his language becomes technical and specific; that day, broad explanations of mood gave way to meticulous balance and bowing as the playing took shape like an increasingly detailed, fine sculpture.

headline: New York’s Public Theater Lays Off 19 Percent of Its Staff
text: The Public Theater, one of the nation’s most prestigious and successful nonprofit theaters, laid off 19 percent of its staff on Thursday as a financial crisis sweeps across the field.

headline: Bastille Day Is Usually a Fireworks Bonanza. Not This Year.
text: Bastille Day in France has long been synonymous with grand fireworks displays over towns and villages, as dancing crowds celebrate their nation’s revolutionary birth.

headline: On his stops in Europe, Biden adds to talk of a new Cold War.
text: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.

headline: Small Town ‘Tradio’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
text: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Suspect Arrested in Serial Killings of Women Near Gilgo Beach
text: The bodies were unearthed near remote Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore more than a decade ago, terrifying residents and leaving the victims’ families bereft. In all, the remains of nine women, a man and a toddler were discovered.

headline: Israeli Unions and Military Reservists Renew Resistance to Judicial Overhaul
text: Union chiefs, business leaders and military reservists in Israel have warned the far-right government that proceeding with its plan to limit judicial powers without a social consensus will open the door for another wave of national strikes and business closures.

headline: Alcohol Poisonings Rise in Iran, Where Bootleggers Defy a Ban
text: When a renowned Iranian artist hosted friends at his apartment in Tehran last month, he served, as he did often, a bottle of homemade aragh, a traditional Iranian vodka distilled from raisins, that he had secured from a trusted dealer.

headline: New Heat Wave Descends on Europe, as It Struggles to Adapt
text: Tourists sheltered under umbrellas as they lined up at Florence’s majestic cathedral this week, looking for shade. Street vendors peddled fans and straw hats. Locals splashed their faces at water fountains, all seeking a respite from Europe’s latest heat wave.

headline: Biden and D.N.C. Announce $72 Million in Fund-Raising, a Substantial Haul
text: President Biden’s campaign announced on Friday a combined fund-raising haul of more than $72 million from April through June alongside the Democratic National Committee and a joint fund-raising committee, a figure that far surpasses what former President Donald J. Trump and other leading Republican presidential candidates have announced.

headline: When You Can’t Believe What You’re Seeing
text: Nobody is quite sure where the term “kayfabe” originated. It may be a bastardized form of pig Latin, something to do with the actual word “fake.” It may have its roots in the culture of wandering 19th-century carnivals, the world inhabited by P.T. Barnum and the confidence men and the salesmen who sold actual snake oil.

headline: In ‘The League,’ Black Baseball’s Field of Dreams
text: Sam Pollard’s documentary “The League” introduces audiences to the teams, stars and little-known figures who populated the Negro leagues by chronicling how Black professional baseball first sprouted. It covers the period from just before the majors instituted a gentlemen’s agreement banning African Americans from playing with white players, to the Negro leagues becoming one of America’s biggest Black-owned businesses, to its demise.

headline: In U.K. Trial, Kevin Spacey Denies Abusing Position of Power
text: Kevin Spacey told a British jury on Friday that some of the sexual assault accusations against him were “pure fantasy” and “absolute bollocks.”

headline: A Victorian Dinosaur Park Finds Its Way in the 21st Century
text: Imagine: It’s 1854. The concept of evolution won’t be introduced for another five years or so. The word dinosaur is only about a decade old. There are no David Attenborough documentaries teaching you about extinct animals.

headline: Butter, Garlic, Spice, Sweetness, Umami and Starch
text: Good morning. Make any recipe more than three or four times and you’re going to change it, either for reasons of taste or expediency, occasionally both. Make that recipe six or seven times and it’s altered forever. It’s no longer the recipe you originally found. It’s yours.

headline: They Put on a Show at Camp, and It Changed Their Lives
text: Molly Gordon and Ben Platt met as children at the Adderley School, a theater studio in Los Angeles that runs after-school programs and summer day camps. There are photos and home videos of them starring opposite each other in some very grown-up shows like “Chicago” and “Damn Yankees.” Two decades later — with the help of the actor-writer Noah Galvin, Platt’s fiancé, and the writer-director Nick Lieberman — they have spun those memories of wonky vibrato, stumbling choreography and an ardent sense of belonging into the feature comedy “Theater Camp,” opening Friday.

headline: Trump Employee Warned of Charges in Classified Documents Case
text: A low-level employee of the Trump Organization has received a target letter from the special counsel Jack Smith in connection with the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents, suggesting that the employee could face charges and confirming that the broader inquiry continues, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Autoworkers Open Contract Talks in a Fighting Mood
text: The three Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers union have begun negotiating a new labor contract in what could become the most contentious talks between the two sides in perhaps half a century.

headline: Belarus says some Wagner fighters are training its forces.
text: Belarus’s Ministry of Defense said Friday that soldiers from Russia’s Wagner military company were training its security forces, offering a rare if vague sign of the group’s presence in the country after its failed uprising against Moscow last month.

headline: U.S. Cluster Munitions Arrive in Ukraine, but Impact on Battlefield Remains Unclear
text: U.S. officials and military analysts warn that American-made cluster munitions probably will not immediately help Ukraine in its flagging counteroffensive against Russian defenses as hundreds of thousands of the weapons arrived in the country from U.S. military depots in Europe, according to Pentagon officials.

headline: In Iowa, Pence Is Put on the Spot Over Jan. 6
text: It was midway through a three-day swing of Iowa for Mike Pence when Luann Bertrand confronted him at a Pizza Ranch.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
text: Since the even-keeled Jamie (Clayne Crawford), an Army veteran, returned home to New Orleans, times have been difficult: His daughter needs an operation. When his impulsive brother, Mic (Max Martini), approaches him about a bank robbery job, the financial gain becomes too much to ignore.

headline: ‘10 Seconds’: Outrage Follows Acquittal in Italy Abuse Case
text: For days, many Italians have flooded social media with two unusual calls to outrage: “#10secondi” and “#palpatabreve,” or “10 seconds” and “brief grope.”

headline: Rick Froberg, Singer of Artful Intensity, Is Dead at 55
text: Rick Froberg, the vocalist and guitarist best known for his work with the influential 1990s post-hardcore band Drive Like Jehu, whose urgent howl was one of rock’s most distinctive voices, died on June 30 in San Diego. He was 55.

headline: George Santos Used New Campaign Cash to Pay Himself Back
text: Representative George Santos, the New York Republican facing federal criminal charges, raised about $179,000 for his re-election campaign from April through June — a modest sum that he used in large part to pay back money he had lent to his past congressional bids.

headline: Education Dept. Cancels $39 Billion in Student Debt for 800,000 Borrowers
text: More than 800,000 borrowers will have $39 billion in federal student loan debt eliminated under a government effort to remedy years of mistakes by the loan servicers that collect payments on the government’s behalf.

headline: Seeing the World Like a Character From a Disney Classic
text: In Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast,” a movie that I’ve loved since childhood, you can tell a lot about people by the way they respond to the enchanted castle. Gaston, the movie’s misogynist boor of a villain, sees a tool to be exploited to sow fear and manipulate others.

headline: Billie Eilish’s Forlorn ‘Barbie’ Ballad, and 10 More New Songs
text: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts
text: A PDF of the Learning Network’s 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts

headline: Little Big Men: ‘The Luckiest Guy in the World’ and ‘Goliath’
text: Pity the poor 7-footer.

headline: Contemporary African Royals, in Regalia and Complexity
text: On a wall of London’s Tate Modern, a large photo from 2012 depicts a seated Nigerian king, wearing a green beaded hat and a lavish robe with a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II printed on the front.

headline: The Big Number: 160,000
text: The union representing television and movie actors is on strike, joining screenwriters on the picket lines and creating Hollywood's first shutdown in 63 years.

headline: The Climate Protesters and the Museums
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Seeks Court Order to Quash Investigation in Georgia
text: In his latest legal maneuver, Donald J. Trump sought a court order on Friday that would throw out the work of an Atlanta special grand jury and disqualify Fani T. Willis, the prosecutor leading an investigation into election interference in Georgia.

headline: How Kristine Hayes Got Retirement Ready
How Kristine Hayes Got Retirement Ready
How David Oscarson Got Retirement Ready
The Weekender
text: The end of the magic world's 50-year grudge. Also in this edition: a boardjacking sea otter and how to sleep better at every age.

headline: Three Big Banks Rake In Better-Than-Expected Profits
text: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year, the lenders reported Friday.

headline: Newly Published, From Nuclear Close Calls to Hollywood’s Greatest Love Affair
text: ANAÏS NIN: A Sea of Lies, by Léonie Bischoff. Translated by Jenna Allen. (Fantagraphics, $29.99.) The writer’s exploration of her sensual inner life — “few know how many women live inside of me,” she says — is gorgeously rendered by Bischoff in rich, undulating, jewel-toned color pencil illustrations.

headline: Little by Little, Pogacar Gains on Vingegaard at the Tour de France
text: Tadej Pogacar gained a little more time on Jonas Vingegaard in the Tour de France on Friday, preferring to chip away at the reigning champion’s lead rather than making one huge move to grab the yellow jersey — and maybe clinch the Tour.

headline: Wonking Out: In Economics, a Game of Teams
text: HBO may have captivated millions with its series “Game of Thrones,” but economists have lately captivated, well, not millions — maybe a few hundred nerds — with their Games of Teams: noisy and sometimes testy public disputes between opposing factions over economic prospects.

headline: What’s in a Screenshot?
text: Last weekend, Sarah Brady, a semiprofessional surfer, posted a number of screenshots of text messages she claims she exchanged with her then-boyfriend, the actor Jonah Hill. In one of the texts, Hill appears to dictate a highly specific list of “boundaries for romantic partnership,” which included not surfing with men, not maintaining friendships with “women who are in unstable places” and not posting pictures of herself in a bathing suit.

headline: 4 Easy Dishes That Embrace Everyday Vegetables
text: It is impossible to separate vegetables from seasonality — especially at the height of summer — but you can be liberated from the anxiety of cooking certain vegetables at specific times of the year. Eat seasonally if you can, but don’t stress if you can’t. There are enough causes of angst in the world; finding vegetables should not be one of them.

headline: Strike Prevents Actors From Promoting Films at Premieres or Festivals
text: It has already been a difficult year for movie theaters, with the North American box office down roughly 20 percent from last year. And that was when actors could promote their films.

headline: Blending Dance and Sculpture Creates a Fresh View of Art
text: The Chicago artist Brendan Fernandes doesn’t need his work to fit neatly into one category. “People ask, ‘Is it a prop? Is it a sculpture? Is it an artwork?’ And I’m like, ‘It’s all those things,’” he said recently by phone.

headline: Listening to Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ References
text: Last weekend, I traveled to Toronto to catch the first North American date of Beyoncé’s Renaissance World Tour. I returned home feeling like the human incarnation of the starry-eyed emoji (so many sparkles!) and with a new appreciation for “Renaissance,” the loose and sprawling album that Beyoncé released this time last year.

headline: Andy Cruz, Amateur Legend, to Find Out if Pro Boxing Fits
text: Andy Cruz and Juan Carlos Burgos squared off and locked eyes on a stage set up in a hotel ballroom in downtown Detroit, and did what boxers usually do when they stand face to face.

headline: Margot Robbie And Ryan Gosling Are Bringing “Barbie” to the Big Screen
Writers Where They Work
text: Helen Gurley Brown, the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan magazine and author of books including “Sex and the Single Girl,” at home in New York in 1979. In a 2012 opinion essay for The New York Times, Jamie Brickhouse recalled that Brown was “thoroughly modern, but not contemporary when it came to email. Letters — typed or handwritten — were her preferred way of communicating.”

headline: A Timeline of Events in the Gilgo Beach Serial Killings
text: An architect who had lived most of his life in Nassau County and worked in Manhattan was arrested on Thursday night in connection with the killings of four women near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore. The discovery of their bodies and seven others in 2010 and 2011 terrified residents and the case remained unsolved for more than a decade.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
text: Including memoirs by Charles McGrath and Doreen Cunningham, fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai, Alexis Schaitkin and more.

headline: My Salary Is Too High. Is It Wrong to Stay in My Job?
text: Less than a year ago, I switched from a job at a nonprofit whose mission I was deeply passionate about to a more senior role at a nonprofit in a different sector. I was very underpaid previously and nearly doubled my salary in this new role. Because this role is outside my field of expertise, however, my job satisfaction is not nearly as high as it was in my previous job.

headline: A Climate Hawk’s Issues With Electric Vehicles
text: I get why the Biden administration is pushing electric vehicles so hard. To stop the planet from overheating, we’ll eventually need motor vehicles to produce zero greenhouse gas emissions, and only fully electric vehicles can do that. Hybrids, which have combustion engines along with electric motors, will always puff some carbon dioxide (and other bad stuff) out of their tailpipes.

headline: Biden Switches Up His Big-Money Operation Ahead of 2024
text: President Biden and his advisers are elevating a new outside group as the leading super PAC to help re-elect him in 2024, making it the top destination for large sums of cash from supportive billionaires and multimillionaires.

headline: How Manga Was Translated for America
text: The wildly popular Japanese genre is now published close to its original form in the United States. That wasn’t always the case.

headline: Actors Picket From Coast to Coast as Strike Gets Underway
text: It was 10 a.m., adoring union members had already more or less mobbed their president, Fran Drescher, and the crowd was growing by the minute.

headline: Review: In ‘The Saviour,’ Past Trauma Is Very Much Present
text: Back stories can be dangerous things. A character besotted with them — especially reductive trauma-filled ones — colludes in her own miniaturization.

headline: Ex-New York Resident Sentenced to Life in Prison for Helping ISIS
text: In 2013, Mirsad Kandic began working with the Islamic State, helping to advance its campaign of global jihad.

headline: How to Mix and Match Your Sheets
text: There's no rule that your sheets have to match.

headline: The Year Is Half Over. Here Are the Books You Might Have Missed.
text: This week on the podcast, Gilbert Cruz is joined by fellow editors from the Book Review to revisit some of the most popular and most acclaimed books of 2023 to date. First up, Tina Jordan and Elisabeth Egan discuss the year’s biggest books, from “Spare” to “Birnam Wood.” Then Joumana Khatib, MJ Franklin and Sadie Stein recommend their personal favorites of the year so far.

headline: Putin wants to travel to South Africa next month. The host country would prefer he didn’t.
text: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is pushing ahead with plans to attend a summit in South Africa next month, even as the host nation grapples with diplomatic and legal fallout of his expected presence, South Africa’s deputy president said on Friday.

headline: My Unexpected Love Affair With ‘Notre Dame de Paris’
text: It seemed as if nothing would ever displace “The Phantom of the Opera” as my most-viewed musical.

headline: The Maverick Design Choices That May Have Doomed Titan
text: Engineers interviewed by The New York Times pointed out several weak points in Titan that were cost-saving departures from proven submersible designs.

headline: Review: Rennie Harris’s Hip-Hop Dance Mixtape
text: In the middle of the opening set at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday, the rapper and performance poet Decora dedicated a song to a man he called a mentor: the folk singer Pete Seeger. The song, played by a full band with horns and electric guitar, was a riff on Seeger’s “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?”

headline: What We Know About the Gilgo Beach Victims
text: The three women that Rex Heuermann is accused of killing — Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman and Amber Lynn Costello — were discovered wrapped in burlap near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore in December 2010.

headline: Students, What Questions About Paying for College Can We Answer?
text: The college admissions process is a fraught one, to put it mildly. But there is one subject that often dominates the discussion: paying for college.

headline: Iowa Governor Signs Six-Week Abortion Ban Into Law
text: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa, a Republican, signed a strict abortion ban into law on Friday, even as a judge heard arguments to suspend it.

headline: How Taylor Swift’s ‘Speak Now’ Became the ‘Scary’ Version
text: Rachel Hunter could not wait to play her new vinyl recording of Taylor Swift’s “Speak Now.”

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tom Hanks
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tom Hanks. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Visitors Are Briefly Trapped at Former Home of Agatha Christie
text: In “And Then There Were None,” the classic novel by Agatha Christie, 10 people are invited to a mansion on a remote island, cut off from the rest of the world. A mystery follows.

headline: Love Letter: A Second Skin to Escape Racism
text: “On gay dating apps, East Asians routinely face dehumanization that reduces us to nothing more than featureless clones in the eyes of others,” Preston Gyuwon So writes in this week’s Modern Love essay.

headline: Despite Aspartame Warning, Beverage Companies Likely to Stick With It
text: About eight years ago, in response to customer concerns about possible health risks associated with the artificial sweetener aspartame, PepsiCo decided to remove the ingredient from its popular diet soda.

headline: Do You Qualify for Biden’s $39 Billion Student Debt Cancellation?
text: Tens of thousands of borrowers with federal student loans are probably wondering: Is my debt load about to get a little lighter?

headline: No One Can Needle Tom Cruise Like Henry Czerny Can
text: “Mission: Impossible” is a franchise known for its big-budget, death-defying stunts, but sometimes there’s nothing more suspenseful than a good old-fashioned, face-to-face staredown.

headline: The House Passes a Defense Bill Limiting Abortion Access
text: House Republicans, under pressure from a faction of far-right lawmakers, narrowly passed a deeply partisan defense bill today that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel. Speaker Kevin McCarthy celebrated it as an effort to force the Biden administration to “stop using taxpayer money to do their own wokeism.”

headline: Jesse Jackson to Step Down From Rainbow PUSH Coalition
text: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., the longtime civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential candidate, plans to step down as president of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, the organization he founded, the group said in a statement on Friday.

headline: U.S. Virgin Islands Seeks $190 Million From JPMorgan in Epstein Lawsuit
text: The government of the U.S. Virgin Islands said in a court filing on Friday that it is seeking at least $190 million in penalties from JPMorgan Chase for the bank’s failure to detect and report the sex trafficking operation run by the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in the U.S. territory.

headline: Vulnerable Republicans Take a Political Risk With Abortion Vote
text: Representative Jen Kiggans, a minivan-driving mom and Navy veteran, narrowly won election last year in her suburban Virginia swing district after a fiercely competitive race that focused on her opposition to abortion rights.

headline: John Uelses, First to Pole-Vault 16 Feet, Is Dead at 85
text: In the 1950s and ’60s, track and field athletes could become models on Wheaties boxes, stars on television and objects of fascination to the news media. There were Bob Richards, an ordained minister and pole-vaulter nicknamed the Vaulting Vicar, and Dick Fosbury, a high jumper whose distinctive leap became renowned as the Fosbury Flop.

headline: Tucker Carlson Turns a Christian Presidential Forum Into a Putin Showcase
text: Bob Vander Plaats, the conservative evangelical kingmaker in Iowa politics, now knows what happens when you turn over your Republican presidential showcase to Tucker Carlson.

headline: Novak Djokovic Relaxes, and Lands in Another Wimbledon Final
text: Six months ago, having just won the Australian Open one year after being deported from the country, Novak Djokovic collapsed in the arms of his family and his coaches in a moment of strained ecstasy.

headline: Hollywood Productions Grind to a Halt as Actors Go on Strike
text: SAG-AFTRA members voted to walk out after contract negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers stalled.

headline: Social Media Restrictions on Biden Officials Are Paused in Appeal
text: A federal appeals court on Friday paused a judge’s order that had blocked much of the Biden administration from talking to social media sites about content.

headline: Pence Raises Just $1.2 Million, Aides Say, in Worrying Sign for 2024 Bid
text: Former Vice President Mike Pence has raised a paltry $1.2 million for his presidential campaign, according to two campaign aides, a sum that raises dire questions about Republicans’ appetite for Mr. Pence in 2024.

headline: University of Tennessee Fined Millions for Cash Payments to Athletes
text: The N.C.A.A. punished the University of Tennessee football program for recruiting violations and direct cash payments to athletes, imposing an $8 million fine and taking away scholarships for what it described as a culture of brazenly skirting rules in hopes of chasing wins.

headline: André Watts, Pioneering Piano Virtuoso, Dies at 77
text: André Watts, a pianist whose mighty technique and magnetic charm awed audiences and made him one of the first Black superstars in classical music, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 77.

headline: For Years, Quiet Gilgo Beach Was a Place of ‘Murders and Mayhem’
text: For a killer looking to hide evidence of his crimes, it was the perfect spot. The straight, quiet stretch of Ocean Parkway would give him plenty of time to listen and watch for coming cars. Just off the road, a tall bramble of bushes and weeds grew so thick and thorny, even trained cadaver-sniffing dogs could barely penetrate it.

headline: Northwestern Fires Baseball Coach Amid Turmoil Over Culture in Athletics
text: Northwestern University on Thursday fired Jim Foster, its head baseball coach, just three days after firing its longtime football coach amid a hazing scandal, deepening concerns over a toxic culture in the university’s athletics.

headline: Wagner Troops Can Keep Fighting, but Without Prigozhin, Putin Says
text: Three weeks after a brief mutiny in Russia by the Wagner mercenary group, President Vladimir V. Putin said its troops could keep fighting, but without their controversial leader, while the government of Belarus said some Wagner fighters were there, training its forces.

headline: An Oasis in the Middle of a Scorching Texas Summer
text: It was six o’clock on Friday morning, at least 15 minutes before dawn over Texas’ capital city, and scores of vehicles had already crowded into the parking lot at Barton Springs Pool, a few miles — and in some ways, an entire world — from the lighted skyscrapers of downtown.

headline: Without Hollywood, What Happens to Los Angeles?
text: Los Angeles County has 88 cities. Ten million people. Two hundred-plus languages spoken.

headline: The Case Against Rex Heuermann: Read the Document
text: Suffolk County, N.Y., prosecutors argued against bail for Mr. Heuermann in a 32-page document that explicitly details the investigation into the Gilgo Beach killings. The New York Times has redacted phone numbers, email addresses, personal addresses and the names of private social media accounts. It has also redacted offensive material that was included in Mr. Heuermann’s internet searches.

headline: Women React to News About an Over-the-Counter Birth Control Pill
text: On Thursday, the Food and Drug Administration approved a hormonal birth control pill, called Opill, to be sold over the counter — a landmark decision that was largely received with excitement by many women and teenage girls in New York. The pill will be sold in stores and online, without age restrictions, beginning early next year.

headline: Where Spies Work
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Jeff Chen is a prolific constructor who collaborates with seemingly everyone in the puzzleverse, including Jim Horne on the indispensable crossword statistics site xwordinfo.com. This is his first solo Saturday grid since 2017; its design is complex (with unusual left-right mirror symmetry), and there’s a ton of wild fill, as one would expect from a guru.

headline: South Korea’s Monsoon Rains Set Off Deadly Landslides and Flooding
text: Four more bodies were recovered from a flooded highway underpass in South Korea, officials reported Monday, bringing the death toll in the recent floods to at least 40. The country has been reeling from intense rainfall from the monsoon, which has swept across the nation in recent days, burying homes, knocking down trees, canceling flights and trains, and cutting power to tens of thousands of residents.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.A.W. Talks Quite Likely to Be Testy
text: “We are seeing in very diverse workplaces a new interest in unions and a willingness to strike. What we don’t know yet is how large this movement is going to become and how far it is going to go.”

headline: Corrections: July 15, 2023
text: An article on Friday about federal prosecutors’ inquiry into President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to overturn the 2020 election misstated who first made public a recording of Stephen Bannon, a former adviser to Mr. Trump, telling associates that Mr. Trump was going to summarily declare he had won. The recording was first reported by Mother Jones, not the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
text: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: What to Watch in the 2024 Money Wars as a Big Deadline Arrives
text: The financial landscape of the 2024 presidential race — the contest’s haves and have-nots, their momentum and desperation — is coming into sharper focus on Saturday, the deadline for campaigns to file their latest reports to the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Carlos Alcaraz Gets a Shot at Novak Djokovic in Wimbledon Singles Final
text: If Carlos Alcaraz were more patient, perhaps he could just wait for Novak Djokovic to fade away. At 20, Alcaraz is 16 years younger than the great champion, and the day is likely to come when Djokovic is either retired or in decline, and Alcaraz can claim the tennis kingdom as his own.

headline: Suspect in Gilgo Beach Killings Led a Life of Chaos and Control
text: At his office near the Empire State Building, Rex Heuermann was a master of the meticulous: a veteran architectural consultant and a self-styled expert at navigating the intricacies of New York City’s building code. He impressed some clients and drove others crazy with his fine-toothed directives.

headline: New York Has $1.1 Billion to Fight Flooding. Will It Be Enough?
text: For Franco Montalto, a flooding expert and engineer, decades of research were suddenly amplified by a real-life emergency in the Adirondacks, where he and his family were on vacation this week.

headline: The Gilgo Beach Victims Were Always More Than Escorts
text: Twelve years ago, on the Monday after Easter in 2011, on a gray afternoon in New London, Conn., Melissa Cann sat at a picnic table on a pier, talking about her big sister, Maureen Brainard-Barnes, who disappeared on a trip to Manhattan four years earlier. While Ms. Cann described herself as a homebody, she said that her older sister was a free spirit, artistic, daring and often clashing with their mother. Maureen had worked as a blackjack dealer, as a clerk at a ShopRite and, in the six months or so before she vanished, as an escort.

headline: How a Master of Japanese Ink Painting Spends Her Sundays
text: “People keep making me older every day,” said Masako Yamamoto, who is 101. “I don’t remember my age anymore, so I’m surprised when people say how old I am.”

headline: Why Sunscreen Is the Only Anti-Aging Product You Need
text: Have you ever looked at the skin on the buttocks of a 90-year-old? Dr. Fayne Frey has. “It’s beautiful,” said the dermatologist and author of the book “The Skincare Hoax.” “There’s very little pigment, there’s very little wrinkling, there are very few blood vessels.”

headline: Rent-Controlled vs. Rent-Stabilized: How Much Can a Landlord Charge?
text: Q: I live in a rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side, and I’d like to know what the rent increase will be this year. I have read a lot about the increases for rent-stabilized apartments issued by New York’s Rent Guidelines Board, but for not rent-controlled apartments. Is there an increase, and will it be retroactive? Will we receive formal notice from a government agency, or is a note from the landlord enough?

headline: Tiffany Haddish Dances to the Beat of Her Never-Ending Internal Soundtrack
text: This summer, Tiffany Haddish plays a marijuana-smoking cat (“The Freak Brothers”), a detective pulled out of retirement (“The Afterparty”), a psychic in a film based on a Disneyland ride (“Haunted Mansion”) and the mother of a child who broadcasts his love life to aliens (“Landscape With Invisible Hand”). For her, the mom is the most relatable.

headline: America’s Foreign Vacations Tell Us Something About the U.S. Economy
text: Forget Emily. These days, a whole flood of Americans are in Paris.

headline: Can A.I. Invent?
text: Generative artificial intelligence, the technology engine powering the popular ChatGPT chatbot, seems to have a limitless bag of tricks. It can produce on command everything from recipes and vacation plans to computer code and molecules for new drugs.

headline: The U.S. and China Are Restarting Climate Talks: Here’s Where Things Stand
text: For nearly a year, talks between the planet’s two biggest polluters, China and the United States, have been suspended as the impacts of global warming have only grown more intense in the form of deadly heat, drought, floods and wildfires.

headline: How a Rocky, Inhospitable Place Became a Beacon of Calm
text: When he first comes upon the advertisement for a job opening on a remote island eight miles off the coast of western Ireland, Robert L. Harris is already primed for sublimity. Visiting a friend in the area in 1985, two years earlier, he and his wife had impulsively joined a small group of tourists heading to Skellig Michael. As the boat nears the island, seabirds wheel in the sky, and everything changes:

headline: Furby, Is That You?
text: The original Furby, released in 1998, had the head of an owl, the beak of a chicken, the feet of a cat, the ears of a pig, the fur of a rabbit, the mohawk of a tufted titmouse and the eyes of a robot, which it was — a robot that whirred, clacked, spoke a made-up language called Furbish and, famously, never turned off (unless its batteries were removed).

headline: Was She Murdered? Kidnapped? Or Did She Fake Her Own Disappearance?
text: This month’s books all feature women making bad decisions — about themselves, about other people and about how to confront the threats swirling around them. Each is unwise in her own interesting way.

headline: In Hollywood, the Strikes Are Just Part of the Problem
text: Existential hand-wringing has always been part of Hollywood’s personality. But the crisis in which the entertainment capital now finds itself is different.

headline: ‘For the Love of the Water’: Tours for the Swimming-Obsessed
text: During the pandemic, when Miriam Leitko couldn’t swim because pools were closed, the lifelong swimmer built a lap pool at her home in Willis, Texas. As soon as travel restrictions were lifted in 2021, she signed up for a weeklong trip to Hawaii with SwimVacation, a Maine-based tour operator that specializes in open-water swimming.

headline: Barbie: A Visual Dictionary
text: Maybe you’ve heard there’s a Barbie movie coming out?

headline: They Put Down Roots In Small-Town Vermont. Then the River Reared Up.
text: For nearly a year, Bex Prasse and Craig Kovalsky had labored to restore every inch of the run-down building where they envisioned their future business, on an up-and-coming Main Street in the small Vermont ski town of Ludlow.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 8-14
text: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: They Lost Their Legs. Doctors and Health Care Giants Profited.
text: Kelly Hanna’s leg was amputated on a summer day in 2020, after a Michigan doctor who called himself the “leg saver” had damaged her arteries by snaking metal wires through them to clear away plaque.

headline: After Suffering Heavy Losses, Ukrainians Paused to Rethink Strategy
text: In the first two weeks of Ukraine’s grueling counteroffensive, as much as 20 percent of the weaponry it sent to the battlefield was damaged or destroyed, according to American and European officials. The toll includes some of the formidable Western fighting machines — tanks and armored personnel carriers — the Ukrainians were counting on to beat back the Russians.

headline: His Sexuality Doesn’t Define Him, but It Can Set Him Apart
text: The hateful email was a surprise, but for Eric Bach, it was not entirely unexpected.

headline: Honoring Tradition, and Personal Choice, With a Persian Wedding Custom
text: Weddings are steeped in tradition, but where do those rituals come from? “Traditions,” a new column, explores the origins of various wedding customs from around the world.

headline: Canadian Politicians Who Criticize China Become Its Targets
text: The polls predicted a re-election victory, maybe even a landslide.

headline: ‘Not for Machines to Harvest’: Data Revolts Break Out Against A.I.
text: For more than 20 years, Kit Loffstadt has written fan fiction exploring alternate universes for “Star Wars” heroes and “Buffy the Vampire Slayer” villains, sharing her stories free online.

headline: In the Land of Football, a Cricket Oasis Rises Outside Houston
text: Drive northwest out of Houston, and as cow pastures wrestle back the flat expanse from the city’s tentacled sprawl, there arise along the road, suddenly, improbably, many, many cricket fields.

headline: To Entice Women to Racing, the F1 Academy Picks Up Where the W Series Left Off
text: It has been 47 years since a woman drove in a Formula 1 Grand Prix, when Lella Lombardi of Italy finished 12th at the Austrian Grand Prix in 1976.

headline: Russian Forces Are Doing ‘Everything They Can’ to Stop Counteroffensive, Zelensky Says
text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that Russian forces were throwing “everything they can” at Kyiv’s troops fighting to retake land in the south and east, again emphasizing the grueling nature of a counteroffensive that is moving more slowly than some allies had hoped and later stressing the importance of their continued support.

headline: Frank Gehry Returns to the Streets of His Canadian Childhood
text: Frank Gehry, the architect whose free-form Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, redefined architecture and set off a surge in museum construction in the late 1990s, was recently back in Toronto, celebrating the beginning of a new project.

headline: Listen Early to This American Life: The Florida Experiment
text: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Reconsidering the Staycation
text: I’ve always been skeptical of the staycation. The coinage is too cute for what feels like a consolation prize: While other people are off exploring the Blue Lagoon by camper van, you get to stay in your very own home and go to your usual supermarket for Cheerios!

headline: At the University of Chicago: Was It Free Speech, or Harassment?
text: To the Editor:

headline: You’re Not Imagining It: Social Media Is in Chaos
text: War is breaking out on social media, and it could radically change how the internet works and how we experience it.

headline: Amanda Gorman: In Memory of Those Still in the Water
text: On June 14, 2023, the migrant boat Adriana capsized off the coast of Greece, killing more than 600 men, women and children who had been crammed onboard the trawler by traffickers. As investigations by the BBC and The New York Times have revealed, officials and coast guard crews failed to treat the crisis as a rescue mission until the last few hours.

headline: Watch Out for the Fake Tom Cruise
text: WASHINGTON — In the 2002 movie “Simone,” Al Pacino plays a director whose star, played by Winona Ryder, walks out on him after saying her trailer on set isn’t grand enough.

headline: How to Break a Country
text: TALLINN, Estonia — Vladimir Putin has compared himself to the czar Peter the Great. But to travel through Eastern Europe is to see how much he has instead caused Russian influence to shrink.

headline: Summer Birthdays, Casablanca and Boreal Forests
text: Dear readers,

headline: And Just Like That, Everyone Is Part of the 1 Percent
text: In honor of the 25th anniversary of the debut of “Sex and the City,” The Cut posted a set of memes from the show on Instagram, including some of the series’s most recognizable lines. When I saw the one about Miranda — “She was a lawyer. He was a sandwich.” — I finally realized what I missed most about the original series that is absent in its reboot, “And Just Like That ….”

headline: Why Deep-Sea Mining Is the Next Battleground in the Energy Transition
text: Surging demand for metals used in electric vehicle batteries has kicked off an international race to mine the deep seas. And there are no rules.

headline: In Brazil, Beauty Is a Right. Are They On to Something?
text: Every person with a toddler knows that her child is in constant imminent peril. Trying to prevent the next near death or disfiguring accident is a parent’s unending occupation.

headline: Wasting Away With Rachael Ray
text: When I was 15, I fell in love with the voice of Rachael Ray. That velvety contralto was the soundtrack of my days in the children’s hospital I hated — with its plaid curtains and kind nurses — but called home.

headline: Search for a Century-Old Shipwreck Turns Up One Even Older
text: In September, a Discovery Channel film crew traveled to Paradise, Mich., searching for two French naval ships that disappeared in 1918. But on a voyage to find them, they stumbled upon another shipwreck that was four decades older.

headline: Home Is Where the Horses Are for a Threatened Culture
text: There is the world, and then there is Appleby.

headline: Poland Doesn’t Want Migrants, but These Foreign Workers Are Welcome
text: Determined to resist a European Union plan to spread the burden of migrants and asylum seekers around the continent, Poland’s prime minister, Mateusz Morawiecki, says his country wants to ensure that “Poles can safely walk the streets,” so it will not take in foreigners it does not want.

headline: Melvin Wulf, Transformative Civil Liberties Lawyer, Dies at 95
text: Melvin Wulf, a constitutional lawyer who reshaped the American Civil Liberties Union into a more aggressive litigator, argued 10 cases before the United States Supreme Court and supported the future Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg in bringing a landmark sex discrimination case, died on July 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Marketa Vondrousova Wins Wimbledon and Her First Grand Slam Title
text: Marketa Vondrousova of the Czech Republic, among the most unlikely of Wimbledon champions, is unlikely no more.

headline: Netanyahu Says He’s ‘Very Well’ After Being Rushed to Hospital
text: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, said he was feeling “very well” on Saturday evening after experiencing mild dizziness and being rushed to a hospital for examination.

headline: Turmoil in Florida’s New State Guard, as Some Recruits Quit
text: Early last summer, complaining that Washington had failed to provide adequate staffing for Florida’s National Guard, Gov. Ron DeSantis announced that for the first time in 75 years he was activating the State Guard, a force of volunteers that could respond to hurricanes and other public emergencies.

headline: Israeli Reservists Threaten Mass Resignations if Judicial Plan Proceeds
text: At least 180 senior fighter pilots, elite commandos and cyber-intelligence specialists in the Israeli military reserve have informed their commanders that they will no longer report for volunteer duty if the government proceeds with a plan to limit judicial influence by the end of the month.

headline: Rare Dinosaur ‘Bonebed’ Is Discovered in a Maryland Park
text: Fossils from animals including dinosaurs and stingrays more than 100 million years old were uncovered in a Maryland park in what experts said could be the widest-ranging discovery of fossils of different species on the East Coast.

headline: Carlos Alberto Montaner, Prominent Critic of Castro’s Cuba, Dies at 80
text: Carlos Alberto Montaner, a writer who escaped Cuba shortly after its Communist revolution, then built a career as one of the exile community’s leading opponents of the Castro regime, died on June 29 at his home in Madrid. He was 80.

headline: The Weather by the Numbers
text: A suffocating heat wave has swept across the South and Southwest in the United States, bringing dangerous temperatures and breaking heat records. Here’s what the numbers tell us about the heat and how it is affecting Americans.

headline: Lionel Messi Signs With Inter Miami, Starting New Era for M.L.S.
text: The greatest soccer player of his era, and maybe the greatest of all time, is coming to the United States for the twilight of his career. Lionel Messi, 36, officially joined Inter Miami of Major League Soccer, the club announced in a release on Saturday.

headline: Ons Jabeur Calls Wimbledon Loss ‘the Most Painful’ of Her Career
text: With the hopes of a country, a continent and a world of tennis lovers who felt she was long overdue urging her toward history, Ons Jabeur fell agonizingly short. For the second time at Wimbledon, and the third time in a year at a Grand Slam, Jabeur had hoped to become the first woman from Tunisia, the first from Africa and the first Arabic speaker to win a major women’s singles tournament.

headline: With a Centrist Manifesto, No Labels Pushes Its Presidential Bid Forward
text: A new political platform focused on cooperative governance by the bipartisan group No Labels has something for everyone to embrace — and just as much for both sides to reject.

headline: Everett Mendelsohn, Who Linked Science and Society, Dies at 91
text: Everett I. Mendelsohn, a Harvard professor who as a scholar of the history of science explored how science’s evolution has been influenced by historical and cultural trends and vice versa, died on June 6 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

headline: The Southwest Braces for Record-Breaking Heat
text: People across the southwestern United States were trying to stay cool on Saturday as a punishing heat wave was posed to break temperature records.

headline: Marga Minco, Who Chronicled Jewish Life in Wartime, Dies at 103
text: Marga Minco, a Dutch novelist who was one of the last of a generation of European Holocaust authors whose works are widely considered literary classics, died on Monday at her home in Amsterdam. She was 103.

headline: Man Sought in Georgia Killing Spree Is Dead, Authorities Say
text: A man wanted in connection with the killing of four people in Hampton, Ga., was fatally shot by police on Sunday, the authorities said.

headline: The Game Is Afoot
text: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Police Capture ‘Survivalist’ Murder Suspect Who Escaped Jail
text: The manhunt for a murder suspect who escaped from a Pennsylvania jail on July 6 by tying bedsheets together to climb down from a roof ended on Saturday when the suspect was captured by the police, the authorities said.

headline: Alabama Woman Who Was Missing After Reporting a Child on a Highway Is Found
text: A 25-year-old woman in Alabama who was reported missing on Thursday night after telling a 911 dispatcher that she saw a toddler walking along the side of an interstate and would pull over to help was found late on Saturday, according to the police.

headline: DeSantis Burns Cash, and Pence Struggles: 5 Takeaways From 2024 Filings
text: As a fuller financial picture of the 2024 presidential race emerged with Saturday’s campaign filing deadline, trouble appeared to lurk below the surface for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Two Sports Connected by Squabbling
text: “This would never go down at Coney Island. Somebody would just get shot.”

headline: Corrections: July 16, 2023
text: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a revival of the play “Orpheus Descending” misidentifies Erica Schmidt’s role in the making of the 2021 film “Cyrano.” She wrote the screenplay; she did not direct.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Airs Bigoted New Covid Conspiracy Theory About Jews and Chinese
text: A conspiracy-filled rant by Robert F. Kennedy Jr. that the Covid-19 virus was engineered to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people has stirred accusations of antisemitism and racism in the Democratic candidate’s long-shot run for president.

headline: A National Treasure, Tarnished: Can Britain Fix Its Health Service?
text: Fifteen hours after she was taken out of an ambulance at Queen’s Hospital with chest pains and pneumonia, Marian Patten was still in the emergency room, waiting for a bed in a ward. Mrs. Patten, 78, was luckier than others who arrived at this teeming hospital, east of London: She had not yet been wheeled into a hallway.

headline: Small, Hidden and Deadly: Mines Stymie Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
text: It was a grisly scene of bloody limbs and crumpled vehicles as a series of Russian mines exploded across a field in southern Ukraine.

headline: DeSantis Sheds Staff Amid Heavy Spending
text: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has started cutting campaign staff just months into his presidential bid, as he has struggled to gain traction in the Republican primary and lost ground in some public polls to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘We Must Go Faster’: Yellen Says Rich Nations Must Speed Debt Relief
text: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen called on Sunday for international creditors to speed up their efforts to provide debt relief to developing countries facing default, arguing that shoring up their deteriorating finances would benefit the global economy.

headline: In Florida, Trump Says DeSantis Has No Path to Victory
text: On the home turf of his chief Republican rival and in his adopted state, former President Donald J. Trump told a sprawling conservative gathering in Florida on Saturday night that it was futile for Gov. Ron DeSantis to keep battling him for the party’s presidential nomination.

headline: Which Presidential Candidates Are Leading the 2024 Money Race?
text: See who has amassed the most campaign cash so far.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
text: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Hot Trends, Hotter Temperatures
text: “The summer of 2023 is shaping up to be a hot one,” two New York Times reporters wrote in June. They meant temperatures, not trends.

headline: In Gilgo Beach Killings, an Arrest Bears Out a Decade-Old Prediction
